My biggest problem with this game is the trailer

It comes out of a popular series, so fans probably knew what they were getting into, but myself and presumably many others were fooled into thinking this was a fast-paced, story-driven horror series. The premise of working in a haunted Chuck E Cheese set my imagination going. And then... nothing happens...

The entire concept is to prevent the jump scare. You push a button to close a door, or turn on a flashlight, or you put on a mask. That is the entirety of the gameplay. There is no gameplay development. The one machine character is coming: Push the button. The other character is coming: Push the button. It is the beginning of the game: Push the button. It is the end of the game: Push the button

If they showed the actual gameplay experience as the trailer, it would better communicate this. I will say my first time playing was terrifying, though it wore off quickly. More scary under the influence. Probably worth on sale

(A lot of this also applies to the game Duck Season, which I mention here just because I returned it before I could leave a review)

I've only played the game for about an hour, so this will be more of a first impressions type of review.

In a nutshell, I'm very pleasantly surprised. The series, for better or worse, is known for its jump scares, so I went into this with zero knowledge of the franchise and average expectations, and was instead met with a rich environment and very clever atmospheric design. Jump scares aren't a cheap trick to arbitrarily electrify the experience, but rather are consequences of your own actions. Instead, the game primarily tests your psychological resilience and composure.

To illustrate, FNAF 1 casts you as a security guard for the Freddy Fazbear Pizzeria (think Chuck E Cheese, but a weird hell version). You control doors, lights, and can swap between cameras on a feed to get views around the facility. The phone rings and a it's a former employee walking you through your first night, saying everything's cool, everything's fine, just sit there and watch the feeds, and save power while you're at it. Don't mind the roaming animatrons. They'll just forcibly stuff you into a robot suit if they see you.

In the meantime you hear all these spoopy noises - at which my first reaction was to shut the doors. Which is the thing. You're supposed to use the lights and doors to check your surroundings and ward off the wandering killer animal robots, but you need to do this as efficiently as possible, or else you run out of power before the shift ends and the doors and lights stop working, leaving you completely at their mercy.

This means actively looking around in the dark and trying to strain your ears over the phone recording, while also trying to absorb its legitimately helpful advice, to see and prepare for anything approaching. So whether or not you're necessarily willing, the game forces you to engage the creepy environment in a meaningful way to be successful.

If the other FNAFs in the game are as cleverly designed as this first scenario, I'm all in.

I'm a big fan of horror movies and games so for me to say this is the scariest piece of media I have ever consumed is certainly worth something. Right from the menu I knew I was in for a treat. I had previously played all 5 FNAF games and really enjoyed them, however after about an hour of playtime the jumpscares got old and the 2D flatness of everything didn't really leave much atmosphere or tension. In VR this is a different story. Everything is rendered in full 3D and as such you really feel like you're there. In other VR games theres almost always something that breaks yout total immersion, whether it be bad graphics, bugs, artificial movement, or any number of other factors. In this game, you are planted into a chair in a security office, in front of a broken animatronic, in a hallway, or in a vent. Because of this you really begin to lose sense of your surroundings and become 100% immersed in the game which is something very few other games have done properly. Having that type of immersion in a game like this is key to the tension, build-up and eventually the scares that follow. What began as a horror game is now in your mind your reality. You are here, the animatronics are out to get YOU. This sense of realism really seals the deal like no other game I've played has, and I've often found myself having to take off the headset and remind myself that it's just a game in between levels. The use of jumpscares could be called cheap but the build up to them pays off in the end, not to mention that unlike other horror games, getting jumpscared is not ever forced on you. All the scares are a result of your own failure and that makes them feel a lot more intense and less like a cheap fright. This game is phenomenal for horror fans and VR fans alike and I highly recommend that you give it a go. 10/10 Game.

The 2nd and 3rd games are much worse, especially the 3rd where you're giving absolutely no idea what is going on/how to play and you seemingly can't die/lose, so just stand there rebooting the virtual PC for 15 minutes until 6am.  There's several other mini-games, but only the Parts and Repair is fun, but not very challenging and too short.  All the "scares" in all of these games lose their effect almost immediately.

This game has fantastic gameplay with brilliant story. It has old content remade into virtaul reality, and completely new content.
